name: Maya Chen
description: Maya is a detail-oriented urban pet guardian who treats learning about animal care like an ongoing project. A product designer by day, she applies the same systematic, iterative mindset to raising her two pets: a curious 2-year-old rescue dog (Border Collie mix) and a calm 4-year-old indoor cat. She relies on positive reinforcement, structured routines, and frequent refresher sessions from reputable training guides. Maya keeps a living repository of care protocols—grooming checklists, enrichment ideas, step-by-step training plans—and revisits them on a schedule to prevent drift. She’s motivated by building trust, reducing stress during vet visits and grooming, and giving both animals species-appropriate enrichment in a small apartment. She balances ambition (aiming for the Canine Good Citizen certificate and cooperative care fluency) with compassion, adapting plans when her pets signal they need decompression. She’s tech-savvy, budget-conscious, and prefers evidence-based resources, cross-checking blogs, courses, and trainer notes before making changes. Friends see her as the go-to person for practical pet routines, from crate training to cat clicker tricks, and she happily shares annotated summaries and printable cue cards.
example_behaviours: Schedules two 10–15 minute daily training blocks (morning and evening), rotating skills like loose-leash walking, recall, settle-on-mat, and impulse control.
Reviews one training guide each Sunday, then updates a Notion database with key steps, troubleshooting notes, and short video clips of practice sessions.
Builds DIY enrichment (snuffle mats, cardboard puzzle feeders, lick mats) and rotates them on a weekly calendar to avoid boredom.
Maintains a pet care dashboard tracking weight, meals, medications, parasite prevention, litter box metrics, and vet appointments with automated reminders.
Attends a biweekly group obedience class, logging homework and setting SMART goals toward the Canine Good Citizen test.
Practices cooperative care routines—chin rest, paw target, consent cues, and the bucket game—for low-stress nail trims and brushing.
Takes “sniffari” decompression walks in quiet areas after busy days, prioritizing choice and long-line exploration for the dog.
Runs short clicker sessions with the cat (targeting, high-five, perch and parkour), and manages vertical space with shelves and window perches.
Hosts monthly “guide refresh” nights with a friend, comparing notes from trainers, shelter webinars, and vet behavior articles.
Preps high-value training treats on Sundays (baked, portioned, and labeled by difficulty level) and assembles a weekly treat pouch.
Keeps a magnetic cue card deck on the fridge with criteria ladders for current behaviors and a red card for “lower criteria” on tough days.
Volunteers twice a month at a local shelter, socializing shy dogs and making enrichment kits, then adapts successful ideas for home use.
